pros:
Resources:  a large company like Boeing has a lot of resources for employees.
People:  as with anywhere, there are a few difficult people, but overall everyone is nice and helpful.
Culture:  safety, healthiness, diversity, and ethics are very important at Boeing.
cons: Lack of job security as the company is currently going through layoffs.

pros: Good benefits and pay.  Pensions going away.   Boeing is eroding their benefits gradually.
cons: Management iis clueless and beyond childish with no idea what a real problem is.   HR and HR Ethics support their incompetence with pretending they are like royalty.  By "royalty", I mean that if a person is the King, then they are still king regardless of their competence.   One manager said that he would have more respect for me if I had "just taken" another employee's screaming at me and clear verbal abuse where he was my "mentor" and if I asked him a technical question in an attempt to learn the job, he would scream at me that I was yelling.  The last manager I had clearly was bipolar and completely irrational but anyone who could do something about it, HR, higher level managers and the union guy all ignored it and pretended that he was perfectly fine and that it was perfectly OK for their pets to work well outside of specification guidelines without going to stress.  One of their pets clearly had a learning disability where she called out a repair on the wrong side of a panel and 3 different times called something a ply lay up table that was not this at all and that was OK with the bipolar manager but being succinct with one too many adjectives was a huge crime.  Also this bipolar manager projected others mess-ups onto others like Virginia taking 2 - 3 hours to review something counted against someone else (me).

pros: Fast paced company offering great benefits to their employees. Many locations around the world if you are one that likes to travel.
cons: The aerospace business is very competitive and as a manager will have to work typically more than 50+ hours a week to maintain your responsibilities

pros: Ability to develop by changing jobs within the company.  Great self-directed professional and academic learning opportunities available online, on-site courses, and through university programs.  Flexible work schedule available and work from home on an as-needed basis.
cons: Easy to get siloed into a job function and begin getting too comfortable.

job_title: Systems Engineer in Huntington Beach, CA
pros: Benefits are good and hours are comfortable.
cons: Very difficult to move to a new position by choice. I was recently moved without a choice other than to accept the move or be laid off. It's easy to get pigeon-holed into being a glorified paper-pusher as a systems engineer making little to no use of the analytical skills learned in a 4-year engineering degree.

job_title: Mechanical Engineer III in Mesa, AZ
pros: Good benefits, good working hours. Overall not a bad company if you are looking for a large company with lots of process.
cons: Lots of process, the finance people try to manage engineering as if everyone were flipping burgers. Need to hire management who have a clue about aerospace.

review_title: Don't waste your time.  Company way out of date!
pros:
Health insurance benefits are good.  401K good, but all benefits are going down.  They are now in the public Norms.  
If you are young you will be promoted well outside of your capacity to do the job.  But if you are over 30...you will have a hard time growing in your career.  If you are over 40...forget about it.
cons:
I had high hopes coming to work for Boeing.  After almost 5 yrs I now understand that Boeing is all talk.  I have never felt more devalued by an employer as I do this one.  Every poor decision (and there are many) is at the expense of the employee.  They have way too much management, and grossly under qualified management.  They believe a person can manage anywhere and skills or interest do not factor into the equation.  I've had 4 managers in 3 yrs.  My current manager is a young kid with no job experience and no experience in our field.  To all new graduates....do not waste your time here, go get some real experience and develop your career, Boeing will not develop you.  

The re-create the wheel each and every day.  No understanding of industry standard, just do it our way.  It is embarrassing.

Lots of career people that are very lazy, do nothing, and manipulate their position.

No opportunities for career advancement unless you want to work outside of your educated field managing people in janitorial.

Decades behind in technology.  Surprising but sadly true.  

Boeing used to be a special company.  Now it is just a slave driving, with people in the wrong jobs leading people blind.

Very disappointing.!

pros: It's a big company and has good benefits.  There are health coach to work with you on establishing heathy lifestyle.
cons: Management does not help with career movement at all.  Movement across groups was not allowed and stopped.  They should do better.

job_title: Graphic Designer/Process Analyst in Bellevue, WA
pros: Diverse workplace with opportunity to develop skills in the IT Technology sector.
cons: Layoffs are a part of life at The Boeing Company and seem to target workers over the age of 55 despite technical knowledge and years of service.

review_title: The return of theory x management
pros: Good pay but not until you max out at 6 yr mark, until then the pay is average but if there's overtime available, that helps. Many amazing co workers. Average medical coverage, not as good as it once was and is projected by some to worsen. Vacation, sick leave and money for education.
cons:
Research theory x management style and that is essentially the model the company has chosen to reinstitute. Some locations/shops may not be as bad but where I was at (Everett, Wa), it was horrible. 

Just a few things employees face; 

You can't stop to tie a shoe without being harassed on why you aren't working. I witnessed them following people around and harassing them almost non stop even while people worked. 

They move people to new planes and new areas without allowing them time to learn the job and regardless of how many people may have an issue with a particular job it's always the employees fault, never the company or how the job was created, the anomoly of the structure itself, etc.  

They won't help you to succeed because really if they don't like you, if you haven't kissed the right butt, if you haven't worked yourself to death, they're wanting you to fail.  Even if you do think, "well, I'm a hardworker, I can do it!" just know when you get hurt (and you will get hurt working like that there or develop health issues) there is NO LOYALTY once you are broken, they'll be gunning to get rid of you. 

They clump people with disabilities together and ship them outside (on projects that don't even seem like a plane truly for sale, shutter to think the hours wasted therel!) and harass them until they quit or get fired. Anyone using FMLA is treated as though they are lazy or abusing the federal law and while some may do that, not all do.  Some just want to get their health together and get back to work.

Management and team leaders even promote the overall toxic atmosphere by openly speaking badly about employees and eachother so there's no real going to work, doing your job and going home. Day shift is worse for it as far as I can tell. 

It's challenging to get into other positions there because it's a long process before you can even apply. It use to be that you could just put in a request but now they've instituted a litany of requirements before you even qualify to put in a move request so most people get stuck and when you're new to a shop, you can't move for a year anyway.  

With forced overtime there is no work/life balance. Depending on where you end up, that's a real possibility. You work to live, you dont live to work. 

They have no values anymore. They go on and on about ethics  while they take entire groups of people with varying levels of disabilities or health issues and send them outside to an area even more unsafe than where they were coming from! 

The company is merely an empty shell of what it once was and if they continue on this course, the pay just won't be worth the excessive health issues one is likely to develop while there, the stress it adds to your personal life..I would rather be paid less and treated with dignity.  

Your life is a precious one. Please think quite carefully before applying here.

job_title: Regional Director of Marketing in Seattle, WA
pros: Great pay and benefits.  Very stable. Countless opportunities and job variety; you will definitely find a role you like.
cons: Boeing is a big and established company with deelply engrained cultures and processes.  It can take years to fully undstwnd the way the company works and this means slow initial career growth.

pros: Good salary, good benefits, good people
cons: Not a lot of opportunity to keep skills up to date

review_title: Great work/ life balance.  You need to know the right people and work the system.  Networking is key to moving up.
pros: Pay is comparable to other Aerospace companies.  Education reimbursement for engineering degrees is 100%
cons: Very political in annual raises and promotions

review_title: Great work/ life balance.  You need to know the right people and work the system.  Networking is key to moving up.
pros: Pay is comparable to other Aerospace companies.  Education reimbursement for engineering degrees is 100%
cons: Very political in annual raises and promotions

review_title: Great place to work on large scale projects that have major impact
pros: Working with new technologies, working on products that impact people around the world, opportunities in many different disciplines and fields
cons: a constant struggle against Bureaucracy and the momentum of getting a product out the door at all costs

pros: Good people to work with, interesting subject matter. Good medical benefits. Able to work four ten hour shifts. Great holiday vacation, 20 day + first year.
cons:
Forced relocation. Employees has to re apply for their current job with only 10 percent getting to keep their current position.
Leadership did not care about people just their hidden agenda.

review_title: System Engineer  and Project Manager at The Boeing Company located in St. Louis, MO.
job_title: Systems Engineer in Saint Louis, MO
pros: People, Upward mobility, competitive pay and benefits
cons: Not much knowledge transfer going on due to the fact that many people are about to retire and are scared that the new younger engineers are out to take their jobs

review_title: Biggest Aerospace Company in the World.
pros: Excellent health benefits and 401K plan.
cons: The retiree medical and pension benefits are now extinct.  The company is going on the cheap letting go higher paid experienced engineers and replacing them with new hires.  When you reach 50, you are on the expendable list.

pros: The company overall has good benefits and flexible schedules. They are understanding of putting family first. There is also a diverse culture.
cons: Most of the positions are not very technical (probably depends on the program you work on from what I have heard) which can be frustrating to an engineer who expected to do engineering work.

job_title: Systems Engineer IV in El Segundo, CA
pros: Lots on good training technical training, work life balance and flexibility, great integrated product teams to work on.  Also offers a great leadership program.
cons: Career advancement is a little slow,  Takes a long time to move to the next level.  More employee recognition

job_title: MP&P Engineer in Long Beach, CA
pros: OK pay and benefits. I work in Research and Development and there is a lot of freedom in my job and travel although this not typical.
cons: Confusing and arbitrary management and finance structure. Advancement means often means changing states.

job_title: Systems Engineer in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Good benefits/401k.  

Well known name.
cons:
No structure to positions or forethought to future project planning.
Pay just below market average but only added skill set is on internal only systems and Microsoft Office.  
If you stay more than 3-5 years and manage to get promoted, your missing skill sets for your new salary will make it very hard to move to another company.

pros: benefits package, mobility within the company
cons: management selection process is very difficult to understand.

pros: The company is huge and you are able to see the final product of you hard work by physically seeing the plays you help build each day.
cons: The staff at Boeing is getting old and lazy, but are at senior positions. After a while younger and harder working peer can grow to resent.

pros: V-22 aircraft is exceptionally capable and you can walk onto it at this location.
cons:
Very little "engineering" at this location (Ridley Park)
Mostly focused on getting parts on the aircraft. When one part is nor working, take it out and get a new one. If you're a s/w engineer this is a great place to work; otherwise, not a great place.

pros:
Size of company - many people to either jive with or hate
Cool product - airplanes are pretty cool
Great benefits
Lots of different job titles
Lots of systems
cons:
Dated technology
Hard headed co-workers
Convoluted systems
force distribution reviews
Underhanded management 
Difficult to move up
Limited in some specialities

pros: Great team and great learning experience, as the work was the same level as an entry level position. Got exposed to several different fields of work. Boeing also did an excellent job with the intern experience by giving multiple facility tours, speaker series with C-suite employees, fighter jet flight simulators and many more.
cons: I had a great internship, and I would recommend Boeing

job_title: Electrical Assembly Mechanic in Long Beach, CA
pros: Good salary for the work and an overabundance of work. Backlog is enormous.
cons: Not too many opportunities for advanced unless you know someone or shmooze up to someone you know

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ridley Park, PA
pros: Good people and great team work. Good benefits.
cons: Does not practice diversity as it claims is a corporate policy. Practices age discrimination for highly qualified and experienced engineers in layoffs, disguised in the name of shareholder value.  Uses threat of withholding separation amounts if any age discrimination legal action is pursued.  Unfortunately, the requirements for age discrimination are difficult to prove in court.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Charleston, SC
pros: Great benefits. Opportunities for travel. Good place for young people to “get their feet wet”. Good example of bad practices.
cons: Poor leadership. Education, Certifications, Experience holds little weight. Schedule trumps quality and safety. Promotes through nepotism. Pride is an illusion.

pros: Freedom to pursue interesting projects and concepts.  Excellent place to create a better work life balance.
cons: Collaboration between different organizational groups is extremely slow and difficult to accomplish.  Lack of accountability and responsibility to complete tasks.

pros: The company has many different functions to learn about and audit.  Depending on where you live there are plenty of job opportunities.
cons: Sometimes the opinions of experienced workers without a lot of Boeing experience are not widely accepted.  Staff and some managers would rather guess at what the boss is looking for instead of asking them.

pros:
This is applicable for employees working in Boeing Test & Evaluation. 
- Great benefits
- Values work / life balance 
- Many opportunities to develop and take the initiative 
- Allows for a long learning curve - people are willing to always help you, provides you many chances to learn, etc.
cons:
- As with many bigger companies, change is slow 
- Many layers of management

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Renton, WA
pros: Boeing offers great pay with an incredible benefits package.  Great place to be able to take care of my family.
cons: There is zero accountability and it's  a great place to just sit in the back and collect a pay check.  Innovation is stifled and schmoozing is the way to get ahead.

review_title: Company Understands Need to Become More Efficient, But It is Actually Becoming Less Efficient
pros:
Petty good benefits
Pretty good pay
cons:
Bureaucracy
Constant threat of layoffs
Loss of company paid pension benefits

job_title: Associate Technical Fellow in Seal Beach, CA
pros: A large company with staying power and many, diverse opportunities.  Large intellectual portfolio.
cons: Myopic with some business decisions, cost cutting to boost efficiency and shareholder value may prove costly in the future.

job_title: Senior Engineering Specialist in New York, NY
pros: High salary, virtual work, job security, ample training, access to world's best and brightest minds
cons: Large company can feel impersonal

review_title: Good ol Boys Club very unfair to minorities
pros: Top pay after 5 years. It looks great on a resume
cons: Your just a number. Not one ounce of care about your home life. Alot of older people who won't retire laziness is infecting the company. It's amazing how much the company doesn't do for it's workers anymore.  Back stabbing is life. No culture no identify

pros: Pretty good benefit.  Work / Life balance not too bad.
cons: There has been a shift in terms of company direction and for the long term, it is not good.  For a technology enabled company, I expect more emphasis on quality and keeping the technical edge in the industry.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Everett, WA
pros: Great company to start at and move around in
cons: While they will pay for your degree if job related (pro), they are limited by merit pools that can't pay you market based on your degree/exp. The solution for decades has been to leave, then come back as a consultant or full time after you have made market value elsewhere.

pros:
Support of a large organization with access to paid training and educations opportunities.

Above average benefits, in comparison to other companies of similar size and complex structure.

Above average salary, relative to other large companies.

Stability, with few layoffs for engineering staff.

Many opportunities to grow and expand the careers of ambitious employees.
cons: Politics, but this can't be avoided in a large company.

pros: The culture is great, most everyone is very helpful and encouraging. Overtime is typically optional and not mandated.
cons: Getting trained for your job is hard to get approved and so a lot of times is on your own time and money. This is especially frustrating as many people are new right now but there are usually people you can go to for help.

pros:
Flexible office timings
Work from home when requested
cons: No work life balance - Employees are treated like 24/7 support providers and we get production support calls even during mid night. I have many such instances wherein I had to be on support call for more than 7 hours starting from evening.

pros:

pros: Benefits are good but could be better
cons: culture is  embarrassingly old fashioned

review_title: Boeing is a great place to kick start your career!
job_title: Summer Intern- IE in Auburn, WA

cons: Compensation isn't high enough and they don't fully tell you what you will be doing before you arrive. A lot of bureaucracy too!

review_title: The company can be a good place to work as long as you get to work for the theory y managers.
pros: It used to be the education program however that is no longer true as it is being modified.
cons: A prevalance of theory x managers.

job_title: Versatile Technologist in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Good benefits, paid holidays 
Good technology
Lots of area to work with
Still there are good people to work with
cons:
There is no leadership.
Higher managements are only interested to outsource the project to their native land
Middle managements are clueless.

pros: great benefits. good work environment with great people. it is really exciting to be able to see new aircraft being built
cons: the environment does sometimes tent to get process heavy with lots of bureacracy. Some of the people have rather outdated notions

review_title: enjoy the professional work pattern here
pros:
relatively good compensation, the longer you work, the better.
opportunities of on hour and off hour education.
good leadership mentor program
cons:
risk of layoff as a new in bad business period.
stable sometimes = boring somehow.
burdens of process and systems
lower raising rate.

review_title: Fast and furious, but a real buzz to work on F/A 18 Hornets.
pros:
Very professional.
Very efficient.
Very exciting.
Very rewarding.
Good fun and nice people to work with.
cons: Expectations of management on new employees to come up to speed in very demanding high tech rolls in a very short period of time is unrealistic!

review_title: Boeing has been challenging but rewarding with many opportunities to grow.
pros: No shortage of challenging work, large company has proven to be more of an asset than a burden.
cons: Advancement seems slower than it needs to be for top performers

review_title: overall It was a very good company to work for.
pros: The non-management people you work with or not will always try to help you with whatever resources they have.
cons: lack of consistency between management on interpretation of same issue. The company cares less than it makes the employees believe.

pros: good money, challenging work and an excellent set of co-workers. This is a world leader in aviation and the opporunities are fantastic.
cons: Too much bureaucracy, the decisions seemed to get muddled up in a sea of paperwork. As a large company with much to risk, it is very conservative.

job_title: Structural Engineer, Houston in Houston, TX
pros: Good benefits.  Affordable housing in Houston.  Great metro setting, multi-cultural, great schools and neighborhoods.
cons: Almost no opportunity to advance at mid-career.  Management ties promotion to short term busines goal, not employee performance.  If you are looking for a company that values its employees and their talents, this is not the right place.  They also value non-technical capabilities more than technical.  Management is very short-sighted.

job_title: Engineer VI in Seal Beach, CA
pros: Good salary and benefits, excellent access to exciting programs, and high tech products to be proud of.
cons: Company hangs onto too many under performing individuals, which keep costs high.

review_title: Learned a lot. great Benefit, great people and environment
pros: Great culture, collaborative people, comfortable environment. Good benefit. Lots of opportunities for development. Good work/life balance.
cons: Crappy food at most cafes, and expensive beverages. Parking sucks, at least in the Everett East Lot. Too much tension between union and the company.

review_title: Long drawn out process from interview to first day on the job.
pros: A lot of advancement opportunities. Great place to work if your a not a new hire.
cons: Required overtime. To much paper work. On a computer more than actually doing your job. Meetings, meetings and more meetings. Classes and more classes.

job_title: Structural and Payload Design Engineer in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Great place to work. Friendly atmosphere, and helpful coworkers. Expectations were clearly layed out up front with clear goals and future positions of leadership within reach.
cons: The site was not in a desirable location, so commuting was a must. The company did not have fitness facilities on site, and little attention was given to suggestions for improvement of work moral.

pros: Good company to work for. There is a lot of opportunity for growth. Great benefits.
cons: Big company. Boeing implements a lot of overhead in all their projects which increases the size of the program team

job_title: Business Operations Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: not a whole lot changes from year to year at boeing.  they are starting to reduce spending which seems to be pouring into the way they handle benefits.
cons: it is a big company and hard to feel like you make a difference.  The products are pretty neat but it is easy to feel disconnected

review_title: Good benefits and pay.  Slow moving company with extensive bureaucracy, and some groundbreaking products.
pros: Good company for those looking for job stability
cons: Extremely risk averse company.  The risk aversion that appropriately applies to flight critical systems/products has permeated to include even small actions that happens within the company.

pros: good working together. strategic company. people care for each other. extremely good benefits. good work-life balance. best company in the aerospace sector
cons: defense side not doing as well because of sequestration. work moving between different locations. culture different at different work sites.

review_title: A dinosaur on its last legs.
pros: Good pay, good stability, diverse company, large company, opportunity for advancement, the opportunity to work with cutting-edge technology
cons: Management is out of touch and  focused too much on their own careers. Plenty of finger-pointing when something goes wrong, which it frequently does.

pros: Big company with lots of opportunity for those willing to work hard and seek it out. There are lot's of areas to move around within the company.
cons: It is a huge, slow moving company and the culture here can be draining.  All management and executives are people that are willing to move every two years to help their career.

job_title: Strategy Analyst in South Seattle, WA
pros: Great people everywhere.  Salary/benefits are solidly good, but not excellent.  Great things really do get accomplished, but they take a long time.
cons: Bureaucracy.  Challenge of being a very small cog in a big, complex machine.  Demographic challenges are ahead.  Aging workforce with a seemingly inability to keep any young people more than a few years.

pros: Good benefits including comprehensive health insurance, 401K match, annual employee incentive plan bonus and long holiday break.  Competitive salary.
cons: Poor work/life balance. Major downsizing and budget cutbacks. Pension plan cut at the end of 2015.  Little opportunity for advancement unless you are willing to locate.

pros: Steady and realtively stress free place to work. Good hours and limited overtime in my field.
cons: Slow pace of work. Projects take long to execute and the pace of change is slow. Younger employees do not generally find many peers.

job_title: Business Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great company as far as salary and work, life balance.
cons: Company lacks vision and says one thing, but does another.  Outdated technologies.  There is a reason why the pay is so good but this company is not listed as one of the best places to work.  Culture is at times borderline unethical and its always about schedule vs quality.

pros: great benefits, great pay, a ton of incentives and events you can go to. always fun to bring your family to "family day"
cons: You are just a number to these people. they do not actually care about you. everyone walks on each other. in my experience im glad i got laid off.

job_title: Business Analyst II in Seattle, WA
pros:
Work/Life Balance
Benefits/401K - high match
Flexible Statement of Work

Hard to move up due to current state of company

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Old Monroe, MO

While line management is doing the best they can under difficult circumstances, senior management is being lazy and making these cuts with a "broad-axe" strategy rather than a more surgical approach based on value and ROI.

pros: Great pay and educational assistance. Insurance is cheap too.
cons: Absolutely have to get the job right.

review_title: Pays well but suffers from the large corporation complex
pros: Great benefits, great pay, and a huge resume builder. Picked up some valuable skills.
cons: Suffers from the slowly turning cogs of huge corporations. Everything takes time, even things that shouldn't. Little room to explore outside of your assigned job task.

review_title: Old and Corporate, lacking innovation and creativity
pros: Great 401k, Sick Time, Good Vacation Time
cons: Struggling to keep up with the times. Very rigid work environment. Creativity and innovation are stifled by  these rigid processes. Tools needed to do your job are unavailable and very difficult to obtain.  Old buildings. Uninspiring gray working environment. You are constantly walking on egg shells wondering if you are following the correct procedures. No training. Arbitrary number based performance reviews.  Too many pretentious business terms used and makes it difficult to understand people.

review_title: A great learning experience even for a seasoned engineer.

review_title: Boeing is a giant, but not a user friendly one!

cons: Going through some layoffs but that is normal in such a cyclical industry.

review_title: Great company to work for, but is facing tough business challenges currently.
pros: Generally treats employees very well and has a very competitive compensation package.
cons: Boeing is having a rough time in the defense market. It isn't winning as many contracts and the business is starting to feel it with several layoffs and other cost cutting measures.

review_title: Good company for entry level positions
pros: Benefits, entry level positions.  There are good leaders in some organizations and unfortunately horrible leaders in others.
cons: Your advancement depends on whether you are liked and how similar you are to the leaders of the organization you are in.

pros: It was nice always having something to do. It seemed to keep the job from getting boring. Liked my team
cons: Sometimes management could be cranky. I hated the traffic coming in and out of work although it was pretty manageable

pros: Working in the Defense side of the company was great since they were audited by the US government and used EVM along wirh logic driven schedules and critical path.
cons: Commercial side of the company was frustrating.They talk the scheduling words but in practice they are way behind the times and they do not implement schedules capable of being analyzed using critical path.

review_title: Boeing is a safe bet if you want a good career while building a family
pros:
Lots of career options
Great benefits
Relevant to global issues of business
cool products (lots of pride)
cons:
Long product cycles
Stodgy with promotions
average pay
net/net benefits are decreasing

pros: I enjoyed the ability to grow in the engineering program. The workload was easy and many people provided help
cons: However, it was very stagnate and plateaued in challenges. I quickly realized that my team wasn't prepared for my fast ability to work through the projects at hand.

pros: Working with some of the most fantastic mechanics there are. Working with a team of Planners supporting 747,767,77 Aircraft on the Flight Line.
cons: Having Upper Management believe that their word will make everything happen correctly, without knowing the intricate support systems impacted by their decision.

pros: Boeing is dedicated and sincere.  Training, day or night, is available for all working there.
cons: It's a fair bet at the Everett factory that you may not be able to park much closer than a half a mile from your work station.

pros: Excellent pay and benefits.  Great people to work with.  Love my boss and love working for a company that I am proud to be affiliated with.
cons: Only some skill codes are allowed to work remotely.  If they offer it for some office jobs, they should offer it for all.  Don't utilize skills of employees to maximum benefit.

pros: Excellent pay and benefits.  Great people to work with.  Love my boss and love working for a company that I am proud to be affiliated with.
cons: Only some skill codes are allowed to work remotely.  If they offer it for some office jobs, they should offer it for all.  Don't utilize skills of employees to maximum benefit.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in South Seattle, WA
pros: Pay and benefits are good.
cons: The new hire background screening process is unprofessional and lacks integrity. The focals struggle with understanding basic job histories of individuals and make outrageous and unreasonable accusations, particularly when it comes to owning a personal business.  Unfortunately, Boeing will continue to lose the talented candidates they so desperately need if this process is not revamped.

review_title: Exactly what you expect from a big corporation
job_title: Propulsion Engineer III in Everett, WA
pros: Decent salary and benefits, great people to work with, good rotation program, offers classes and workshops, union
cons: Slow process, mediocre salary, have to fight for career advancement, managers seem to be hit and miss, frequent layoff and reorganization, keeps moving jobs out of washington

review_title: Boeing culture and how they treat hourly employees.
job_title: Tooling Inspector B in Everett, WA
pros: Great health care benefits and decent pay.
cons: Boeing is not flexible with work hours. You may be forced to change location. Vacation is very little to start out. In general all hourly employees are treated as numbers to be moved around to the best advantage of the company bean counters without consideration to employee well being.

job_title: Assembly Mechanic in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The pay is decent for younger hires. The benefits are pretty good. There are many options as far as career growth.
cons: The management is completely clueless. They care more about "business" than about how their own business works.

pros: Boeing has great benefits and is good at retaining employees in the workplace. It is a great place to start working.
cons: Boeing has a ton of history and over the years processes have built up to the point where you are constantly jumping though hurdles

job_title: Business Operations Specialist in Lafayette, LA
pros: The company allows me to fulfill my desires to succeed. I love the organization, benefits, and people. The job is my life's ambition
cons: The company is demanding. Days off are not easy to come by. The stress is intense. Sometimes your job requires you to carry the sight of the world.

review_title: Opportunities to those who seek it
job_title: Programmer Analyst IV in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great benefits, good people to work with.  Many opportunities in such a large company.
cons: Still very bureaucratic.  There are many people trying to change it but it is quite a big ship to turn.

pros: Strong support system for all employees. Competitive pay and the Benefits are second to none. Would return to Boeing without a second thought.
cons: Work life balance can be a challenge in some jobs but not all jobs fall into this category. Big company that takes awhile for changes to happen.

pros: This is the best job ever. Never had a job who pays well until boeing came. Will retire here
cons: i have no complains whatsoever. I just want to continue to improve my skill and just work everyday withe nicest people around

pros: The learning experience is endless. Plenty of different job opportunities.
cons: Inexperienced managers that lack people skills. The "good ol boy" system runs rampant and the majority of managers are all friends, relatives, etc. Experienced and educated employees are getting skipped over for a buddy or a relative.

pros:
Great digital learning campus
Flexible work patterns
Excellent employee benefit schemes
Competitive compensation
cons:
Lack of high performance culture
Too casual and indisciplined
Institutional politics
Indecisive leaders
Too flat management structure
Non committal talks by leadership

review_title: Ok Job, but just a job
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Long Beach, CA
pros:
Great Benefits
Great Job Stability
Great Job Flexibility
cons:
Mundane at times
Experience level is everything with respect to job level and promotion opportunity
Company is overstaffed
Process is everything

job_title: Computing Technologist III  in Bellevue, WA
pros: Great benefits, great people, diversity of challenges, great products.
cons: In the research labs, money is harder and harder to come by.  People in the divisions are resistant to new ideas.

review_title: Management Sucks but you work with World Changing Items
pros: Working with the Top of the Line Technology and making a difference everyday in the world.
cons: Too many managers and each one doesnt know what is going on with the main people doing the hands on job. Management needs to listen more to employees and have a open mind.

pros: Company really takes you in and makes you feel comfortable as an intern.  The Seattle program is fantastic.  A lot of responsibility, not like a get coffee kind of internship.
cons: Job placement after isnt as good as they say it will be.  Really make every effort to seek out opportunities and do info interviews with managers.

pros: Provides great professional development opportunities for employees in engineering functions due to complex, high level of technology involved
cons: Poor career development opportunities for employees, poor overall management and strategic direction, below industry average compensations

review_title: Employees are proud to work here and airplanes are pretty cool. Great place for engineers, not business people.
pros: Work/Life Balance, Cool Product, People who care about each other, Education Reimbursement, Phenomenal Healthcare Plan, chance for travel
cons: bureaucratic, hard to make decisions quickly, squashes creativity for business employees, horrible commutes, slow advancement, slow to develop young employees/don't use the talent they have, seniority complex

review_title: Review of Boeing as a organization.
pros: Great job to start your career. Also great place to work while raising a family.
cons: Management can be into themselves and forget we all are part of the company.

review_title: Despite management cliches, it's actually a serious engineering company.
pros: People are serious about their jobs, and management at least pretends to be open to new ideas.
cons: Boeing is currently out to kill off the unions and is moving more work to god-awful parts of the country no evolved person would be caught dead in.

review_title: Despite management cliches, it's actually a serious engineering company.
pros: People are serious about their jobs, and management at least pretends to be open to new ideas.
cons: Boeing is currently out to kill off the unions and is moving more work to god-awful parts of the country no evolved person would be caught dead in.

review_title: Boeing is amongst one of the Best companies to work for. I was employed there for over 32 years.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Long Beach, CA
pros: Competitive pay, good benefits and employee incentives. Good educational program
cons: Male dominate culture. Need to apart of the "Good Ole Boy" club

pros: The opportunities and benefits are great.  Most are willing to go the extra mile and help when you most need it.
cons: The aerospace industry is very volatile, which is really no reflection on Boeing.  But the instability can be  a bit unsettling.

job_title: Flightline Readiness Technician in North Charleston, SC
pros: There's always something to learn and something new to do. Everybody I work with has been great. Also the benefits can't be beat. All without a union.
cons: Some of the managers really have zero idea how to manage people. The bean counters have been worried about the wrong things

review_title: Boeing great in commercial but not so good on the defense side
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Huntington Beach, CA
pros: Boeing supports on going skill development.  It has great benefits.  The salary is quite generous.  The company gives out bonus annually
cons: Boeing defense side is not doing well.  Consider coming into the company on the commercial side.  Some development are quite antiquated, but some are quite innovative.

pros: Pay is better than similar jobs elsewhere. Education benefits are good.
cons: Company doesn't recognize Engineering degrees from some WA universities. Difficult to move up or around. Constant layoffs create adversity.

job_title: Systems Engineer in Huntington Beach, CA
pros: Nice benefits, friendly people, and a flexible schedule.
cons: It really depends on what program you end up on.  Many have no growth opportunities and all the good work is kept by the more senior level employees.  No new business is coming in which means trying to drag out the life span of programs that have no new products to offer.

pros: Good benefits, though in the name of chasing record profits the employees are asked annually to pay a little more, cause that's what the market will bear.....
cons: Entirely dysfunctional at the executive level. 80% of execs could be cut and no one would miss them, more work would get done and profits just may go up naturally...

pros: Company had excellent educational reimbursement program
cons: Job promotion for management position is a mystery!!   Who you know works more than what you know for mid to senior level management.

pros: Benefits are still somewhat decent
cons: Work life Balance that Boeing promotes is non-existent. Boeing use to be very flexible with people's schedule and working from home... they aren't anymore.  As a college grad I stayed because of the benefits and flexibility... Now there is no reason to stay other than I like my manager.

pros: Overall, company does try to provide competitive benefits structure and growth opportunities for employees who demonstrate leadership attributes and high performance.
cons: Limitations due to defense contracting budgets. Quantity of processes can slow down agility.

pros: Great pay and benefits. They instilled a team culture where every persons input was valued. A very diverse work force.
cons: Long hours and long weeks. The Boeing credo where people are their number one asset did not seem to be for all of us former McDonnell Douglas employees.

job_title: Staff Analyst in Long Beach, CA
pros: Very average pay and benefits. Virtually impossible to get fired.
cons: The work itself was boring and didn't seem to be adding value. A lot of down time. Bored, depressed coworkers who were going through the motions, waiting for another job or retirement. Management was disengaged. Archaic facilities lacked common office amenities:  no windows, dirty bathrooms, filthy kitchens and common areas, janitorial staff emptied trash cans only once per week.

job_title: Administrative Layout Focal in Lexington, MA
pros: Boeing has the best management team. They treat you like adults instead of little kids, they don't swaddle you and expect you to get the work done
cons: The positions are not always permanent. You could get laid off at any moment without a long notice at all, especially if you are a contracted employee

review_title: Favorism is the key factor for promoting
pros: There are many extremely nice people who are very knowledgable and willing to help. Decent benefits and pays.
cons: favorism is the key factor for promoting. what you can do is less important than who you know.

review_title: Not a place to build a happy career
pros: Great Benefits, good flexibility, paid Christmas break
cons: Takes awhile to climb the corporate little to no upward mobility. Over worked. Company laying off older employees to replace them with new employees that can do al their work and accept lower pay. Poor Management. Employees are not appreciated.

pros: Good healthcare benefits, wages are better paying that other in industry, it is a great place to finish off a long career.
cons: Harder to leave company due to wages, harder to change industries due to stigma

pros: Good benefits, company contributions to 401K, education is 100% for technical advanced degrees.
cons: Major organization re-structure does not align with industry standards and have negatively impacted overall morale.

review_title: Working in Boeing Engineering Design - Competition for jobs
job_title: Technical Designer IV in Arlington, WA
pros: Great work Catia V5 limited only by your imagination
cons: Intense competition for jobs, bullying, verbal and physical assault on company premisis not investigated for lack of witnesses

review_title: Great Company, Good Peope, One Vision.
pros: Work environment, benefits, building airplane, annual pay raise, diversified workforce.
cons: inequality corporate ladders, high millennial turnover rate, politics, overdone safety, overpriced on-site food service.

pros: good job balance and working life
cons: less salary hike which should be the important thing

pros: Benefits and state-of-the-art factory environment
cons: Slow, non-innovative people and culture. Difficult to get things done. Too many layers of management. Information is everywhere, but also nowhere at the same time. People are there for benefits and don't seem to actually enjoy their jobs.

pros: Large company, exciting and innovating work, cutting-edge technologies, good benefits
cons: Employee benefits are slowly eroding away year by year, with the excuse always being that the company has to remain competitive and/or to bring the company inline with industry standards.  And that all might very well be true, but it still sucks for the employees.

review_title: I had no idea rigidity could be so ambiguous.
pros: Boeing's Learning Together Program can't be beat.  100% tuition coverage for continued education without any hoops to jump through.
cons: Very rigid with many requirements to fulfill on even the simplest of procurements but the requirements are described so poorly it's unbelievable.

pros: Great overall benefits, flexible work environment, possible to pay advance degree.
cons: Lost a lot of benefits that made the company to be the best. Also breaks down engineering rolls and small chucks not allowing you to expand your knowledge and experience to the maximum.

review_title: Used to be a good employer
job_title: Chief Software Engineer in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Large company with a lot of products, and lateral mobility
cons: Boeing does not value software. Financial outlook is terrible and layoffs are announced.

review_title: Good company with an identity crisis
job_title: Quality Assurance Manager in Mesa, AZ
pros:
Good pay and benefits
Easy to move around to gain valuable experience
cons:
Executive managers are out of touch with problems plaguing company
Most executives hide issues rather than report them to the top levels to ask for help in correcting issues

review_title: great company to work for because of the benefits, but that won't keep me there forever
job_title: Tech Writer in Saint Louis, MO
pros: GREAT benefits package, very flexible with work schedules
cons: if you're a painfully stereotypical american that only likes beer and baseball and wants to vote republican, you'll find no downsides to working at boeing in st. louis

review_title: Systems integrator great for older workers, not so much for young technically gifted engineers.
job_title: Systems Engineer in Huntington Beach, CA
pros: The benefits, especially the education reimbursement program.
cons: Lack of technically competent engineers. The systems integrator role Boeing plays reduces the amount of exposure to young engineers.

job_title: Programmer Analyst in Long Beach, CA
pros: world class benefits, world class tuition reimbursement, friendly staff, opportunity for growth if you are aggressive and under the right manager
cons: overall poor management and if you get the wrong manager you won't be promoted or given adequate raises for a long time

pros: Salary and Benefits are very competitive, but it certainly does not outweight the culture of this company.  It is hostile and outdated
cons: Everything else is terrible, and I've been here over 20 years.  If you want your pride, respect and morale beat up every single day, this is the place for you

review_title: Good place to work, good people and great products.
pros: Overall it's a nice place to work, Boeing makes some amazing products.  It's always exciting to see the giant airplane being built in the factory.
cons: Sometimes the work is not particularly exciting, as with most big companies, there can be plenty of bureaucracy, but for the most part it was manageable.

pros: The division at which I worked was pretty forward thinking. The IT department worked towards, and attained, certification in software development. I learned a lot from co-workers and management, and was treated with respect.
cons: No real downside to working there. The industry is a volatile one, very dependent upon defense funding from the federal government as well as sales to other governments.

review_title: Large company for lots of potential for career growth
pros: Lots of growth opportunities, especially with a large population of the employees set to retire within the next decade, creating opportunities for younger employees to gain more responsibilities.
cons: It is easy to get caught up in some of the politics/bureaucracy that come with working for such a large company. Need to stay motivated to avoid these pitfalls.

review_title: Boeing is a great place to work giving people lots of different opportunities.
job_title: Finance Analyst in El Segundo, CA
pros: Boeing benefits/pay provide a comfortable lifestyle. Good work/life balance. Exciting products are made here, you are at the forefront of a lot new technology.
cons: Advancement is difficult. In a big company, you get lost as a number. There are multiple layers of management, so decisions are made very slowly.

review_title: They could be so much better. They used to be and that's the problem.
pros: Health Care and matching 401k.
cons: Very militaristic,controlling and creativity is discouraged.  Peter Principle prevails.

review_title: A company on the edge of technology and with a lot of integrity.
pros: There are many opportunities at this company, it is a matter of finding the right mix for the individual and management
cons: As with many large companies there is a lot of overhead

review_title: Great work life balance, exciting products

- Exciting products
cons:
- Execution of policies dependent on first line management discretion and are inconsistently applied.
- Access to growth opportunities very greatly depending on immediate management
- Current culture of divesture in employees, reinvestment in short term shareholder value

job_title: Sheet Metal Assembler in Ridley Park, PA

review_title: Used to be great, now is looking to simply improve profit margins.

review_title: good to learn, bad to grow

cons: If you are a developer, it is not good place for you to grow as you will not use much of the programming.

pros:
With the ability to flex schedules and plenty of pto you can really balance well. 

Many intelligent older engineers willing to share knowledge and experience.

Not as many younger coworkers to relate to. 
The company sees you as a number and an expense.

pros: Great benefits, used to have a pension, awesome insurance. Yearly cost of living increases, some stock bonuses, occasional merit increases.
cons: After leaving I now know salary could be better compared to the rest of the market. Pension no longer offered.

pros: Really good benefits. Nice to get overtime for a salary job.
cons: You end up working all the time. Typically have to work every other weekend.

pros: Excellent benefits, great career growth opportunity, and a work/life balance that can't be beat. Recommend to anyone looking for a long-lasting career.

pros: Great Benefits, Passionate Engineering Teams, Vision.
cons: Unclear management chains, difficult to get promoted within a group without changing jobs or location, and pay scales on the lower end for the work that is done. Slow to change and adapt to new policies and newer generations.

pros: Stable. If you want to do the same thing without change for the rest of your life, you'll love it.
cons: Antiquated. Mediocrity is engrained in the culture. Not agile. Bad communication from leadership.

pros: Big company, not going anywhere, steady work, can be exciting depending on project, 40 hour work weeks
cons: Advancement became next to impossible, nearly every job requires clearance, old buildings, ridiculous deadlines, never any time to refactor

pros: Friendly, dedicated employees. Lots of exciting new technology to research and see in use.

Good old boy club alive and strong.  DO NOT believe the open and honest culture.  You should expect retaliation for feedback and a silent HR and leadership team.

pros: Tons of opportunity to try new things and learn new skills. Just get in the door and you can go from there. Even changing from shop floor jobs to office jobs is possible with the right work ethic.
cons: It's like a small city. You can feel like a small fish sometimes. That can be bad or good, depending.

review_title: Great opportunities and areas to focus on.

pros: Good Benefit package for medical and 401k annual bounces and raze.

pros: Good pay, great benefits, intelligent coworkers at the working level.

pros: Defense side is much more flexible than the commercial side as far as work schedules.  Great benefits, salary, people.

pros: Great benefits, and depending on the team it can have great people.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in El Segundo, CA
pros: great salary, benefits and flexible schedule.  pride of working in prime spacecraft industry experience.

review_title: All Good Things Must End Due to Mismanagement

cons: Favoritism, Nepotism, and general rumor spreading done by SA management. Inabilitly to enact positive change to benefit employees. Horribly ineffective HR department. Misallocation of resources. And a hostile work environment due to managers mistreating employees.

pros: Great business structure. Diverse work environment.

job_title: Procurement Agent IV in Bothell, WA

cons: The only con I see is based on the current market pressures and cost down. It has driven a do more with less mentality

pros: You will be able to provide for your family with the compensation and benefits package

review_title: Possibility of full time employment has decreased immensely
pros: Good Pension, VIP(voluntary investment matches) and Health benefits
cons: Unless you're senior management or an Engineer, you're probably not going to get hired full time. They've been replacing full-time employees with 32/hr week contractors.

pros:
Amazing Benefits
Flexible work schedule
Great work atmosphere
cons: Managers are performing a day job function instead of being able to be a manager.  They pretty much have their hands tied when it comes to investing in their employees and developing them to better their career.

pros: Lots of opportunity to work in different areas
cons: Slow to make and implement strategic decisions, not making the right strategic decisions.  Management incentive model drives bad decisions and behavior.

pros: Great training for new employees,  benefits are great, and once within the company there are opportunities to move to other groups and positions within the company

review_title: Great salary and benefits but bad morale due to massive layoffs.

cons: no job stability, ageism. Management lies as a tactic to get people to quit in order to avoid paying severance package.

review_title: Great work environment with friendly people but management a bit uptight

cons: Work is sometimes stressful to meet orders or when there are issues.

job_title: Electrical Engineer in Oklahoma City, OK

cons: I most enjoy specialized in-depth technical work, however, Boeing works mostly at a broad system integration scale.

review_title: Ready for flying safely 737 max , congratulation
pros: Hamble team management and responsible and brave to face reality wisely
cons: There is no downsides to work in this company , it is the best opportunity to be a part of its history.....

job_title: Manufacturing Change Management Specialist in Everett, WA

review_title: Good place to work for a few years to take advantage of the educational benefits and then to get out.
job_title: Test Engineer in Saint Louis, MO

pros: Communication, salary, they listen to you, when you have a problem, they will stop and talk to you about it

Making necessary changes to compete.

Common big company pitfalls:

review_title: Great Experience -- however you have to be driven or you'll die of boredom
